.class public auto ansi beforefieldinit UIViewController extends MonoTouch.UIKit.UIResponder implements class MonoTouch.Foundation.INSCoding, class MonoTouch.ObjCRuntime.INativeObject, class MonoTouch.UIKit.IUIAppearanceContainer, class MonoTouch.UIKit.IUIContentContainer, class MonoTouch.UIKit.IUIFocusEnvironment, class MonoTouch.UIKit.IUITraitEnvironment, class System.Collections.IEnumerable, class System.IDisposable

Docs.summary: Base class for classes that manage the interaction between Model classes and View classes

remarks.para: The class is the base class of the View Controller hierarchy. View Controllers manage s and other s. An iOS application has a single window, but many screens, each of which may contain several s. Managing those screens is complex and requires responding to both user input and changes in the model (problem domain). This management and coordination is the job of the .
A has 3 major responsibilities:

item.term: Layout out its component s. This includes sizing, responding to orientation changes, etc.
Restructure the display in response to input events or the state of Model classes
Translate user input into platform-neutral Model service requests

remarks.para: iOS provides a number of standard view controllers such as , , and . In general, the application developer should prefer to use standard view controllers to create the overall display structure. Using standard view controllers provides consistent, standard behavior and makes it easier for the app to conform to the iOS Human Interface Guidelines.

Additionally, the application developer generally needs to implement one or more “Content View Controllers”. These are often derived directly from or . Content View Controllers are where the application developer writes the custom code to satisfy the s responsibilities described previously. In applications that take advantage of Xamarin Studio’s Code Behind facilities for Apple’s Interface Builder, much of this custom code will be automatically generated by Xamarin Studio. Applications written using MonoTouch.Dialog do not generally need a custom-written Content View Controller, but may use one for architectural consistency.

A single View Controller may have many views and subcontrollers, but typically a single View Controller will have a single root view and be primarily concerned with controlling that one view or it will be primarily concerned with maintaining a collection of subcontrollers. In the following example, taken from the “Hello World iPhone” sample, a Content View Controller of type HelloWorld_iPhoneViewController is instantiated and set to be the for the application’s window:

By contrast, the following code taken from the "iOS Standard Controls" sample demonstrates how a uses an application-defined NavItemGroup to manage a series of other s. In this code, the second parameter to the NavItem constructor is the specific subtype desired when that item is selected in the table:

The following illustration shows the classic relationship between Model, View, and Controller classes. The arrows indicate dependencies: the View depends on the Model class to provide data, the Controller depends on the Model class for information about what to display and depends on the View class to do the drawing. This diagram is idealized: there would be several classes in the Model, several Views, can actually use to determine their , etc.

item.term: The Model class has no knowledge of the associated View and Controller classes. This allows the Model to evolve independently and greatly improves maintainability and portability

Event handlers are used between the areas of concern. This allows for strongly-typed that only contain the data relating to that event. This improves maintainability by limiting the client object’s access to the event-provider’s scope.

The Controller reacts to events both from the View and from the Model. A might, for instance, handle a input event by requesting the Model to convert between Celsius and Fahrenheit temperature units. Conversely it might respond to a Model “too hot” event by changing the display (making visible a warning icon or somesuch). The View updates its display in reaction to new data provided by Model events. View classes should be as passive as possible. One of the most common mistakes in non-maintainable software is a View class that acts as a Controller or that "reaches into" the Model for data rather than accepting values passed in as event arguments.

format.h2: UIViewController, Interface Builder, Storyboards, and Nib files

remarks.para: XCode, Apple’s IDE, contains Interface Builder (“IB”), a tool that allows user interfaces to be created interactively and saved as “Nib” files (these are saved in XML format with the “.xib” extension). Xamarin Studio generates Code Behind classes for nib files and generally these will be subclasses of . Starting with iOS 5, application developers can use “Storyboards” to visually specify navigation amongst individual s. For more on Storyboards, see Introduction to Storyboards.

Xamarin Studio fully supports universal applications that use a single to control multiple s customized for the iPad or the iPhone. As long as the s used by the two devices share the same elements, they can share the same Outlets and Actions, as described in the "iPad + Universal (iPhone + iPad) Apps" guide.

It is not necessary for the iPhone and iPad versions to use the same UI elements, however. The application developer may wish to take advantage of the increased screen real-estate and larger set of controls available on the iPad. In such cases, the application developer should create separate s and load them appropriatel using code similar to the following, again taken from the “iPad + Universal (iPhone + iPad) Apps“ guide. The choice of the to be loaded is determined at runtime based on a call to .
If you want to provide state restoration in your class, you need to manually add a method with the following signature to your class:

item.description: Choose from a set of possible activities
Presents content view controllers as a series of pages
Presents content view controllers one at a time, with a header and optional toolbar
A standard for selecting and taking photographs.
A standard for reviewing and editing video and audio files.
Top-level controller that presents view controllers one at a time, selected by a toolbar along the bottom of the screen.
A standard view controller that presents a term and it's dictionary definition.
An iPad-only view controller that presents side-by-side view controllers.
Efficiently displays a large number of cells, arranged in a flexible manner.
Efficiently displays a large number of cells, arranged vertically.

remarks.para: Starting with iOS 8 a series of idioms were introduced into iOS 8 to assist developers in creating applications and UIViewControllers that would work with different form factors, like both iPhone and iPad.

This replaces the pre-iOS8 design that focused on supporting two different form factors (iPhone or iPad) in a particular orientation as well as supporting the transitions from one interface orientation to the other.

New applications should take a number of variables into consideration when laying out the elements on their UI. These include the available size in the canvas, UserInterfaceIdiom (iPad or iPhone), the display scale, and both the vertical and horizontal size classes. The first one is the size of your main view, while the rest are stored in the .

Rotation is now considered a class size change. For example an iPhone held in portrait mode has a regular height and a compact width. When you switch it to landscape, it becomes a compact height and a regular width.

Applications can override to react to changes to any of the user interface traits. This method will be invoked during rotations or changes to the user interface that affect the size class of the application.
The method is invoked when rotation takes place.

.NET developers will be familiar with Microsoft-promoted architectures that serve the same goal as MVC. Both Model-View-Presenter (MVP) and Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) strive to maintain the separation between Model classes and display classes. Developers familiar with MVP will be used to Model data flowing through a coordinating Presenter object towards the View rather than MVC’s model in which Views directly subscribe to Model events. It is possible to do an MVP architecture in iOS by increasing the responsibilities of a . The defining characteristic of MVVM is the use of databinding to ensure that View objects are reactive. iOS controls do not support databinding so MVVM is not possible. MVVM developers will be used to more of a "firewall" between View and Model objects than is available in MVC. MVVM developers should remind themselves to ensure their View objects are as reactive as possible and are not reaching in to the Model for data or taking over Controller responsibilities.

MonoTouch.Dialog (“MT.D”) allows complex UIs to be rapidly built using declarative statements. As opposed to applications built using Apple’s Interface Builder, most MT.D applications use the predefined and do not create their own subclass of . For more information, refer to the namespace documentation and the article Introduction to MonoTouch.Dialog.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Default constructor that initializes a new instance of this class with no parameters.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSCoder coder) cil managed

Docs.param: The unarchiver object.
Docs.summary: A constructor that initializes the object from the data stored in the unarchiver object.

remarks.para: This constructor is provided to allow the class to be initialized from an unarchiver (for example, during NIB deserialization). This is part of the protocol.

If developers want to create a subclass of this object and continue to support deserialization from an archive, they should implement a constructor with an identical signature: taking a single parameter of type and decorate it with the [Export("initWithCoder:"] attribute declaration.
The state of this object can also be serialized by using the companion method, EncodeTo.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObjectFlag t) cil managed

Docs.param: Unused sentinel value, pass NSObjectFlag.Empty.
Docs.summary: Constructor to call on derived classes to skip initialization and merely allocate the object.

remarks.para: This constructor should be called by derived classes when they completely construct the object in managed code and merely want the runtime to allocate and initialize the NSObject. This is required to implement the two-step initialization process that Objective-C uses, the first step is to perform the object allocation, the second step is to initialize the object. When developers invoke the constructor that takes the NSObjectFlag.Empty they take advantage of a direct path that goes all the way up to NSObject to merely allocate the object's memory and bind the Objective-C and C# objects together. The actual initialization of the object is up to the developer.

This constructor is typically used by the binding generator to allocate the object, but prevent the actual initialization to take place. Once the allocation has taken place, the constructor has to initialize the object. With constructors generated by the binding generator this means that it manually invokes one of the "init" methods to initialize the object.
It is the developer's responsibility to completely initialize the object if they chain up using the NSObjectFlag.Empty path.

In general, if the developer's constructor invokes the NSObjectFlag.Empty base implementation, then it should be calling an Objective-C init method. If this is not the case, developers should instead chain to the proper constructor in their class.

The argument value is ignored and merely ensures that the only code that is executed is the construction phase is the basic NSObject allocation and runtime type registration. Typically the chaining would look like this:

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyorassemblyhidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(native int handle) cil managed

Docs.param: Pointer (handle) to the unmanaged object.
Docs.summary: A constructor used when creating managed representations of unmanaged objects; Called by the runtime.

remarks.para: This constructor is invoked by the runtime infrastructure () to create a new managed representation for a pointer to an unmanaged Objective-C object. Developers should not invoke this method directly, instead they should call the GetNSObject method as it will prevent two instances of a managed object to point to the same native object.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void Dispose(bool disposing) cil managed

param.name: disposing
param.para: If set to , the method is invoked directly and will dispose manage and unmanaged resources; If set to the method is being called by the garbage collector finalizer and should only release unmanaged resources.

Docs.summary: Releases the resources used by the UIViewController object.

remarks.para: This Dispose method releases the resources used by the UIViewController class.

This method is called by both the Dispose() method and the object finalizer (Finalize). When invoked by the Dispose method, the parameter disposing is set to and any managed object references that this object holds are also disposed or released; when invoked by the object finalizer, on the finalizer thread the value is set to .

Calling the Dispose method when the application is finished using the UIViewController ensures that all external resources used by this managed object are released as soon as possible. Once developers have invoked the Dispose method, the object is no longer useful and developers should no longer make any calls to it.

For more information on how to override this method and on the Dispose/IDisposable pattern, read the ``Implementing a Dispose Method'' document at http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/fs2xkftw.aspx

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.UIKit.UIRectEdge EdgesForExtendedLayout { get; set; }

Docs.summary: Specifies how the should extend the layout of this .

remarks.para: Prior to iOS 7, the did not visually underlap parent elements such as the status bar, navigation bar, or toolbar. In iOS 7, it typically should.

The specifies to the how the edges of this should be extended for underlap. The default value of specifies that all edges should be extended to underlap, while specifies an extent similar to that in iOS 6 or earlier.
The following image illustrates the difference: when is set to , the drawing rectangle of the underlying underlaps, but if is set to , the drawing rectangle is restricted to the interior.

Docs.summary: Specifies whether the toolbar should be visible when this is pushed onto a .
Docs.value: if the toolbar should be hidden, if it should be visible.

remarks.para: When a is a child to a , it may display a toolbar at the bottom of the screen. If that is not the desired behavior, the application developer should set this property to .
If a sets this to , the toolbar remains hidden until the is popped from the stack. This will effect other s that are currently visible.

Docs.summary: Constant used to identify broken hierarchies.

remarks.para: This identifier is used to identify the exception thrown when a is added to the hierarchy, but that 's is not part of the hierarchy. In other words, the hierarchy and hierarchy must be consistent.

Docs.summary: The current orientation of the interface.

remarks.para: This value represents the rotation of the interface necessary to keep the interface upright.

Note that in portrait modes, the will be the opposite of the . For example, if the device is rotated clockwise from upright so that it is in portrait mode with the home button on the left, the value of the will be but the value of will be .

Docs.summary: if the current is in the process of being dismissed.

remarks.para: The dismissal process is bookended by the functions and . While those are executing, this property will return , at all other times, it will return .

Docs.summary: if the current is in the process of being presented.

remarks.para: The presentation process is bookended by the functions and . While those are executing, this property will return , at all other times, it will return .

Docs.summary: if the current is in the process of being added to a parent .

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void LoadView() cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes the property.

remarks.para: This method should not be called directly. It is called when the property is accessed and lazily initialized. Generally, the appropriate will be loaded from a nib file, but application developers may override it to create a custom . This method should not be overridden to provide general initialization on loading a view, that belongs in the method.

item.term: Overriders who create a custom should not call base.LoadView().
Overriders should assign the custom to the property.
The s created by this method must not be shared with other s.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.UIKit.IUIViewControllerPreviewing RegisterForPreviewingWithDelegate (MonoTouch.UIKit.IUIViewControllerPreviewingDelegate previewingDelegate, MonoTouch.UIKit.UIView sourceView);

Docs.param: The delegate that controls the display of peeks and pops in response to variations in user-applied pressure.
The view, in the receiver's view hierarchy, that supplies the peek, or preview, view.
Docs.summary: Registers this view controller for 3D Touch peek and pop operations.
Docs.returns: The context for the preview.

remarks.para: App developers call this method to register this view controller as the one that displays preview and commit force gestures, specify the source view that will remain visually focused prior to peeking, and specify the delegate that responds to forceful touch from the user. App developers can rely on automatic life cycle management for the context that is returned, or manually release it by calling the method.

Application developers who want to preserve the option to unregister for 3D Touch peek and pop must store a reference to the instance that is returned by , so that they can later pass it to the method.
This method should typically be called in an override of in the initial of the app.

Docs.summary: Notification constant for ShowDetailTargetDidChange
Docs.value: NSString constant, should be used as a token to NSNotificationCenter.

remarks.para: This constant can be used with the to register a listener for this notification. This is an NSString instead of a string, because these values can be used as tokens in some native libraries instead of being used purely for their actual string content. The 'notification' parameter to the callback contains extra information that is specific to the notification type.
If you want to subscribe to this notification, you can use the convenience . method which offers strongly typed access to the parameters of the notification.
The following example shows how to use the strongly typed Notifications class, to take the guesswork out of the available properties in the notification:
The following example shows how to use the notification with the DefaultCenter API:

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.UIKit.UIView View { get; set; }

Docs.summary: The view managed by this view controller.

remarks.para: A contains a single as the root of its view hierarchy. Such s must only be referenced by a single .

When accessed for the first time, this property will lazily initialize the by calling the function. To avoid lazy loading, the application developer should use the property, which will return if the has not been instantiated.

In iOS 6 and later, 's with active references are not scavenged in low-memory situations. In earlier versions, during low memory situations, this property may be unloaded and only re-initialized as display conditions warrant. In other words, object identity may not be preserved and the state of the will be lost unless application code takes steps to preserve and restore it. (Prior to unloading, the method will be called. That method and are the appropriate places to take such steps.)

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void ViewDidAppear(bool animated) cil managed

Docs.summary: Called after the is added to the view hierarchy.

remarks.para: This method is called after the that is this ’s property is added to the display hierarchy.
Application developers who override this method must call base.ViewDidAppear() in their overridden method.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void ViewDidDisappear(bool animated) cil managed

summary.para: This method is called after the that is this ’s property is removed from the display hierarchy.
Application developers who override this method must call base.ViewDidDisappear() in their overridden method.

Docs.summary: Called after the has laid out its subviews.

remarks.para: This method is called after this ’s has laid out its subviews (which happens when the property is modified).

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void ViewDidLoad() cil managed

Docs.summary: Called after the controller’s is loaded into memory.

remarks.para: This method is called after this 's and its entire view hierarchy have been loaded into memory. This method is called whether the was loaded from a .xib file or programmatically.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void ViewDidUnload() cil managed

Docs.summary: In iOS 6 and later, this method is never called. In prior versions it was called when the controller’s view was released from memory.

remarks.para: In iOS 6 and later, 's that are referenced by live objects are not scavenged during low-memory situations. In other words, in iOS 6 and later, this method is never called. In previous versions, application developers may override this method to ensure that all references to the scavenged have been removed. When this method is called, is .

Docs.summary: Returns the if it has been instantiated; otherwise, returns .

value.para: A return indicates that the has not yet been loaded.

remarks.para: Because are relatively heavyweight compared to T objects, the object is lazily initialized. Developers can test if the has been initialized by calling this method, which returns if the had not yet been loaded. Developers can call to force the loading of the .

Docs.summary: Called prior to the being added to the view hierarchy.

remarks.para: This method is called prior to the that is this ’s property being added to the display hierarchy.
Application developers who override this method must call base.ViewWillAppear() in their overridden method.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void ViewWillDisappear(bool animated) cil managed

param.name: animated
param.para: If the appearance will be animated.

summary.para: This method is called prior to the removal of the that is this ’s from the display hierarchy.
Application developers may override this method to configure animations, resign first responder status (see ), or perform other tasks.
Application developers who override this method must call base.ViewWillDisappear() in their overridden method.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void ViewWillUnload() cil managed

Docs.summary: In iOS 6 and later, this method is never called. In prior versions it was called prior to the controller’s view was released from memory.

remarks.para: In iOS 6 and later, 's that are referenced by live objects are not scavenged during low-memory situations. In other words, in iOS 6 and later, this method is never called. In previous versions, application developers may override this method to ensure that the state of the view can be restored when it is re-initialized.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool WantsFullScreenLayout { get; set; }

Docs.summary: if the view should overlap the status bar.

remarks.para: When this property is at it's default value of , the 's 's is sized so that it does not include the area under the device's status bar (the area at the stop of the screen that shows, e.g., signal and carrier, battery charge, etc.). If set to and is set to , the will be visible behind the status bar.

Docs.summary: Deprecated method sent during the first half of a rotation. Application developers should instead use .

remarks.para: Two-step rotations are deprecated and application developers should instead use single-step rotations (see ).
When this method is called, the is set to the old orientation.

remarks.para: This method is called from with the animation block associated with a user interface rotation. When this method is called, the is set to the new interface orientation and the of the 's have been modified.
